```{r Step_1, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
# Load Required Functions:
source(file = "muFunc.R")

# Load Required Packages:
wants <- c("dplyr", "psych", "pacman", "ggpubr",
           "PerformanceAnalytics", "lubridate", "DescTools")
has <- wants %in% rownames(x = installed.packages())
if(any(!has)) install.packages(wants[!has])
pacman::p_load(char = wants)

# Load Required Data:
data = read.csv(file = "data/Data_Test_12.csv", header = TRUE)

# Show Data:
headTail(x = data, top = 2, bottom = 2)
```

```{r Step_2, fig.width=4, fig.height=4, dpi=600}
# Assumption Checking:
# 1. It is assumed that the x and y values originate from a bivariate normal distribution,
# and that the relationship is linear.

# Use Shapiro-Wilk Normality Test:
shapiro.test(x = data$prec_mashhad)
shapiro.test(x = data$prec_sabzevar)

# Normality Plot:
ggqqplot(data = data$prec_mashhad, ylab = "Mashhad Prec. (mm)")
ggqqplot(data = data$prec_sabzevar, ylab = "Sabzevar Prec. (mm)")

# Visualize Data Using Scatter Plots:
ggscatter(data = data, x = "prec_mashhad", y = "prec_sabzevar", add = "reg.line",
          conf.int = TRUE, xlab = "Mashhad Prec. (mm)", ylab = "Sabzevar Prec. (mm)")
```

```{r Step_3, fig.width=4, fig.height=4, dpi=600}
# Method 1:---------------------------------------------------------------------
x = data$prec_mashhad
x_bar = mean(x = x)

y = data$prec_sabzevar
y_bar = mean(x = y)

n = length(x)

# Correlation Coefficient (r)
r = (sum((x - x_bar) * (y - y_bar))) / (sqrt(sum((x - x_bar) ^ 2) * sum((y - y_bar) ^ 2)))

# Test Statistic (t)
t = (r / (sqrt(1 - (r ^ 2)))) * sqrt(n - 2)

# Compute the critical values at 0.05 significance level (two tailed).
alpha = 0.05
t.half.alpha = round(x = qt(p = (1 - alpha/2), df = n - 2), digits = 4)

# P-value for Spearman's rank correlation coefficient (Two Tailed).
p_value = 2 âˆ— (1 - pt(q = t, df = n - 2))

cat("t-score: ", t, "\n")
cat("Critical values: ", c(-t.half.alpha, t.half.alpha), "\n")
cat("P-value: ", p_value, "\n")

plotDistStat(dist = "t",
             to = 8,
             alpha_level = 0.05,
             statistic_point = t,
             p_value = p_value)

# Method 2:---------------------------------------------------------------------
# use cor.test function:
cor.test(x = data$prec_mashhad, 
         y = data$prec_sabzevar, 
         alternative = "two.sided",
         conf.level = 0.95)
```
